name: Trifluoroacetic anhydride
Reason: The basic unit to consider here could be acetic acid, which has a melting point of 16.6°C. The substitution of three hydrogen atoms with fluorine atoms in trifluoroacetic acid lowers the melting point due to the high electronegativity of fluorine drawing electron density away from the COOH group, weakening intermolecular hydrogen bonding, estimated at about -80°C shift from acetic acid to trifluoroacetic acid. Further conversion to an anhydride form generally increases the melting point due to additional dimer formation and stronger intermolecular forces, but since this compound is a symmetric anhydride, the large electron-withdrawing effect of the six fluorine atoms could be substantial, potentially outweighing the dimerization effect. An estimation of +20°C is given for the anhydride formation, but it appears that the high electronegativity and bulk of the fluorine atoms leads to a greater decrease in the melting point.
